docs.snippet: A deep winter freeze has settled on my part of the world. Last night, as the roast chicken and scalloped potatoes were coming out of the oven, the power went off. The lanterns were brought out and dinner resumed for the hour or so it took the elec...
docs.lead_paragraph: A deep winter freeze has settled on my part of the world. Last night, as the roast chicken and scalloped potatoes were coming out of the oven, the power went off. The lanterns were brought out and dinner resumed for the hour or so it took the electric company to patch things back together. The New York shows were that fast-receding train; suddenly, on Saturday morning, they were no more.
docs.abstract: A deep winter freeze has settled on my part of the world. Last night, as the roast chicken and scalloped potatoes were coming out of the oven, the power went off. The lanterns were brought out and dinner resumed for the hour or so it took the electric company to patch things back together. The [...]

headline.main: Talk to the Newsroom: Sports Editor Tom Jolly

docs.snippet: The Bagger prays that the strike is really over, so that he can get back to being a full-time Oscar ninny....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger has a small admission to make. While the writer's strike has been storming along, it's been a little difficult to get excited about the micro and macro aspects of the Oscars. As long as people were out of work and both the outcome and the future were in doubt, the correct answer to the question of whether another film could sneak through for best picture if "No Country" and "There Will Be Blood" split the voters, was, "Who cares?"
docs.abstract: The Bagger prays that the strike is really over, so that he can get back to being a full-time Oscar ninny.

headline.main: A Victory That Actually Means Something

docs.snippet: Tomorrow's pantheon of movie stars -- or a least one magazine's best guess....
docs.lead_paragraph: Lynn Hirschberg of the New York Times magazine muses on where fame comes from and anoints a new crop of the soon-to-be- famous in a remarkable portfolio of photos. The nascent pantheon includes a few folks who have been seen around Oscar-town this season.
docs.abstract: Tomorrow's pantheon of movie stars -- or a least one magazine's best guess.

docs.snippet: Two Oscar ninnies bloggers, who know a thing or two, have put out a podcast that is actually worth listening to....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger is not a huge podcast fan -- they're not searchable, for one thing, and it's pretty obvious, listening to them, why most of the writers being recorded type for a living. But he made an exception for the gab session between Tom O'Neil, he of the Gold Derby, and Sasha Stone, empress of Awards Daily. Among other juicy bits, they fire back at some of the mainstream journalists who are in such a snit about the rise of the blogocrats. And they do a fine job of explaining how "No Country," a film with lots of rough edges, ended up leading the Oscar pack.
docs.abstract: Two Oscar ninnies bloggers, who know a thing or two, have put out a podcast that is actually worth listening to.

headline.main: Can These Girls Talk, or What?
